text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

CCDM 32.7.1.1, Overview, provides an overview of the procedures for Counsel review and approval of certain frequently asked questions (FAQs) that the Executive Counsel determines should be issued in the form of “Fact Sheet FAQs.”
) CCDM

, Overview, provides an overview of the procedures for Counsel review and of certain frequently asked questions (FAQs) that the Executive Counsel determines should be issued in the form of “Fact Sheet FAQs.” (
) CCDM
Review of Fact Sheet FAQs, sets forth procedures for Counsel review of Fact FAQs. (
) CCDM
Format of Fact Sheet FAQs, speciﬁes the content and format required for Fact FAQs, including model disclaimer language.
CCDM 32.7.1.2 Review of Fact Sheet FAQs, sets forth procedures for Counsel review of Fact Sheet
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
Chief Counsel Notice 2022-006, Procedures for review and posting of certain frequently asked questions (FAQs) on IRS.gov, issued June 30, 2022, is superseded.

of Fact Sheet FAQs

) The Chief Counsel Office of Executive Counsel (Executive Counsel) will as the primary point of contact for the review, clearance and issuance of Sheet FAQs. In addition, the role of Executive Counsel includes determining which FAQs are subject to these procedures and coordinating review of Sheet FAQs among the various stakeholders, including the IRS (as further described below), the Associate Offices with subject matter jurisdiction, the relevant Division Counsel, the Chief Counsel, and Treasury. (

) These procedures apply to FAQs prepared for newly enacted legislation other contexts, such as emerging issues, as appropriate, where no Internal Revenue Bulletin guidance, including regulations, has been issued. The procedures provide clarity regarding taxpayer reliance on Fact Sheet FAQs and ensure that Fact Sheet FAQs are archived and searchable on IRS.gov, so taxpayers can later locate the version they relied on should need to do so. (
) Questions as to whether these procedures apply to any particular set of should be addressed to Executive Counsel. (

) Counsel attorneys and reviewers who are drafting FAQs or reviewing FAQs that have been drafted by the IRS should coordinate with Executive the FAQs address newly enacted legislation or an emerging issue to if FAQs are subject to these procedures. (

) The Associate office will draft and approve the Fact Sheet FAQs under procedures including, if appropriate, Treasury review. Once that process is completed, further review, clearance and issuance will be coordinated by Executive Counsel. Executive Counsel will coordinate with other Associate offices, the Deputy Chief Counsel, Senior Advisor to the IRS Deputy sioner for Services and Enforcement (DCSE), and the Treasury as appropriate, to ensure that all interested parties have the opportunity to review. (

) Executive Counsel will coordinate with the Associate Office and with cations and Liaison (C&L) to ensure that Fact Sheet FAQs are incorporated into an IRS Fact Sheet linked to an IRS News Release using appropriate format and disclaimer language, as described in this section

) The IRS Fact Sheet should include: • Reciprocal links between the Fact Sheet and News Release. • Standard disclaimer language with a link to the Reliance Page, a number assigned by C&L, and the date. • If the Fact Sheet revises or updates a prior Fact Sheet, a note at the top of the page indicating the FAQ is a revision of a prior Fact Sheet, the number of the prior Fact Sheet, and the speciﬁc FAQs from the Fact Sheet that are superseded. Link between the prior and current Fact Sheet (and corresponding News Releases). (

) The following model disclaimer language should be used on all Fact Sheets containing Fact Sheet FAQs: Below are answers to frequently asked questions (FAQs) related to [ﬁll the blank]. These FAQs are being issued to provide general to taxpayers and tax professionals as expeditiously as possible. Chief Counsel Directives Manual
Review of Fact Sheet FAQs 32.7.1

These procedures apply to FAQs prepared for newly enacted legislation and other contexts, such as emerging issues, as appropriate, where no Internal Revenue Bulletin guidance, including regulations, has been issued. The procedures provide clarity regarding taxpayer reliance on Fact Sheet FAQs and ensure that Fact Sheet FAQs are archived and searchable on IRS.gov, so taxpayers can later locate the version they relied on should they

(07-21-2022) Format of Fact Sheet FAQs

Reciprocal links between the Fact Sheet and News Release. Standard disclaimer language with a link to the Reliance Page, a number assigned by C&L, and the date. If the Fact Sheet revises or updates a prior Fact Sheet, a note at the top of the page indicating the FAQ is a revision of a prior Fact Sheet, the number of the prior Fact Sheet, and the speciﬁc FAQs from the prior Fact Sheet that are superseded. Link between the prior and current Fact Sheet (and corresponding News Releases).

these FAQs may not address any particular taxpayer’s speciﬁc and circumstances, and they may be updated or modiﬁed upon review. Because these FAQs have not been published in the Revenue Bulletin, they will not be relied on or used by the IRS a case. Similarly, if an FAQ turns out to the an inaccurate of the law as applied to a particular taxpayer’s case, the law control the taxpayer’s tax liability. Nonetheless, a taxpayer who and in good faith relies on these FAQs will not be subject to a that provides a reasonable cause standard for relief, including penalty or other accuracy-related penalty, to the extent that results in an underpayment of tax. Any later updates or to these FAQs will be dated to enable taxpayers to conﬁrm the which any changes to the FAQs were made. Additionally, prior of these FAQs will be maintained on IRS.gov to ensure that who may have relied on a prior version, can locate that if they late need to do so.
For more information about reliance see: https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/ general-overview-of-taxpayer-reliance-on-guidance-published-in-the-internal-revenue-bulletin-and-faqs. (

) If applicable, the disclaimer language should include a statement that the Treasury Department and the IRS continue to consider publishing additional guidance in the Internal Revenue Bulletin on the issues addressed in the Sheet FAQs. (

) The standard disclaimer language should appear at the top of all Fact Sheets containing Fact Sheet FAQs, with a link to the Reliance Page. In the ﬁrst sentence of the disclaimer, a description of the legislation or guidance to the FAQs relate should be ﬁlled in within the space provided. (

) If the Fact Sheets are late updated or modiﬁed, a “Note” in bold should be added at the top indicating that the Fact Sheet is a revision of a prior Fact Sheet. Sample language for revised/updated Fact Sheet FAQs: Note: These FAQs supersede earlier FAQs that were posted in FS-
XX-XX [date]. (
) When the Fact Sheet FAQs are ready to issuance, the IRS Fact Sheet and

The standard disclaimer language should appear at the top of all Fact Sheets containing Fact Sheet FAQs, with a link to the Reliance Page. In the ﬁrst sentence of the disclaimer, a description of the legislation or guidance to which the FAQs relate should be ﬁlled in within the space provided.
